results.title: Choplifter II for Game Boy
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge case and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In this sequel to Choplifter!, the player has to fly a rescue helicopter through levels to pick up stranded hostages. Complicating matters are the planes, bullets and even aggressive birds that get in the helicopter’s way, not to mention buildings and hills. Rescuing a given number of hostages will complete a level and saving more hostages than required leads to extra points and lives. Inversely, taking too much damage or losing too many hostages will lead to lost extra lives.

results.title: Balls of Steel for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description:
Balls of Steel is a top-down pinball computer game that features five fully-animated pinball tables, each with its own theme, missions, and special bonuses. One of the tables is themed on Duke Nukem, a franchise that Balls of Steel’s publisher, Apogee Software, developed. This tie-in continues to Duke Nukem series itself, where the pinball game appears in several releases.

Balls of Steel plays on a top-down scrolling screen, with an animated dot matrix display at the bottom mimicking the displays of actual pinball tables. As with its real-life counterpart, it shows the player score and animated graphics. Each table can also be viewed in its entirety. High scores are awarded with a “powerball” bonus mode, and could be posted on the “WorldScores” website for a global ranking, although this feature has since been discontinued.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy is a sports game based on Australian Rules Football. The game is played from a third-person perspective, where the player has the ability to perform the basic actions of the footy player currently in posession of the ball. A player can pick one of eighteen Australian football teams to compete against the computer, or against another player on the same system. The game includes a Kick to Kick Training Session, a Single Game mode and a Season mode where one, four or six players can play multiple games that culminate in the Grand Final.

A player wins by having the most points at the end of the game. Points are added by either kicking a goal (six points) or a behind (one point). To move the football, a player with the ball can either kick or handball the ball, and a player without the ball can either mark the ball or tackle an opposition player with the ball. The game was only released in Australia.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: Melbourne House, Psion Software and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Penetrator for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Penetrator is a side scrolling shooter for one or two players for the Commodore 64. The player flies a fighter across the screen from left to right, dodging terrain and enemy shots and shooting enemy structures. Players can accelerate and brake their fighter but prolonged braking can stall it. Enemies become more accurate the longer the player is exposed to the radar and the danger level is shown on the player’s console. The game can also be customised for landscape and the number and positions of enemy missile and radar bases.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1982 by Melbourne House

results.title: The Muncher for ZX Spectrum 128
results.creator_credit: Rob Howard, Beam Software, Gremlin Graphics Software and Zero Wait
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, badge and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.

results.title: Play It Again I: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files - some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.
